response.answer_text: This is ultimately dependent on your definition of “life”. If we were to take the biological definition of life requiring, Homeostasis, Organization, Metabolism, Growth, Adaptation, Response to Stimuli, and Reproduction, and simply adjusted those parameters to fit the construction of robots, then theoretically, they would be alive. The only issue is that currently robots are not created from small cell like structures, but organization as a whole exists. It is very reasonable to assume that humans could create robots that perform all of the above functions. Most robots already do most of those functions. As a corollary, “Is AI alive?” then, if humans could create an AI that was virtually indistinguishable from humans, and because the ultimate boundary of perception is literally you, then you could not say that they are not alive. That doesn’t mean that it IS alive, but you can’t say it is not.

I think we’re getting uncomfortably close. Could machines have become self-aware without our knowing it? – George Musser | Aeon Essays “Our machines could become self-aware without our knowing it. We need a better way to define and test for consciousness” As the cartoon cat Mooch would say, “Yesh.” I just picked up my iPhone and asked Siri if she’s alive. She said, “That’s a rather personal question, Martin.” See? Already our machines aren’t letting on. Either that, or she’s a hopeless prude. Or maybe she’s just a little shy, and we need time to build trust. Is it possible that machines will be alive when we believe they are? If Siri were switched out by a real person talking to me from Apple HQ, how would I know? Ok, with the current Siri I could probably figure it out pretty fast. But how long before I can’t? That’s when she’ll pass the Turing test, at least as far as I’m concerned. With someone brighter than me, it will take a little longer.

No , they will never be alive like humans. It will never be possible for humans to create something as amazing as human consciousness. Those who claim that this can happen, they have no idea, how amazing and sublime they themselves are.

Like many classification schemes, this is a rather wooly imprecise and, I believe, destined to fall into disrepute. There was a time that most scientists believed that there was something very special about the chemistry of life, so much so that the subject of chemistry split into organic and inorganic chemistry. Soon however organic chemicals were synthesized from inorganic ones but we still use the same terms of organic and inorganic. So, I believe, will happen with the concept of life. It was a useful concept when we were less sophisticated but we are now getting to the point that we can see the full spectrum of chemicals from humanity to elements with no step change in liveliness.
